fields.descriptive_line: Cloak and doublet, worn by Henry Irving in the role of Phillip II, in Tennyson's 'Queen Mary', 1876, and by Gordon Craig as Cromwell in 'Henry VIII', 1892
fields.physical_description:
[cloak] Ribbed silk black armhole-cloak faced with black looped wool. As with doublet, has quilted fabric lining to add bulk.
[doublet] Doublet of black ribbed silk, with attachments for short cloak and heavy neck-chain. Altered by turning down the collar and substituting black braid for the original trimming. Puffed sleeveheads and fitted, possibly slightly shortened, sleeves. Closes at the front, edge to edge, with hooks and loops. Two buttons at each sleeve cuff and two rows of braid down the centre front and hem.Quilted lining to provide bulk.  Fitted at the waist. Evidence of wear at collar.
fields.dimensions:
[cloak] Length: 94 cm Back of neck to hem, Width: 49 cm Across the shoulders, Width: 52 cm Across the chest
[doublet] Length: 74 cm Back of neck to hem, Width: 45 cm Across Shoulders, Width: 49 cm Across the chest
fields.public_access_description:
Henry Irving (1838-1905) wore this costume as Philip II of Spain in Queen Mary by Alfred, Lord Tennyson (1809-1892).  Irving based his appearance in this role on a portrait of Philip II by Titian.  Although Philip only appears in the third and fifth acts, Irving won unanimous critical praise for his characterisation of a cruelly malevolent individual.  Accounts of his performance also refer to the dramatic visual effect of costume and make-up.  His portrait in this role was painted by James McNeill Whistler (1834–1903).

The costume was later adapted for the character of Thomas Cromwell in Irving’s 1892 production of Henry VIII.  

Irving became a professional actor in 1856, and learned his trade in regional theatres until 1866, when he came to London.  He joined the Lyceum Theatre company under the management of H. L. Bateman in 1871, winning great acclaim that year for his psychologically developed characterisation of the guilt-ridden inn-keeper Mathias in Leopold Lewis’s melodrama The Bells.  He took on the responsibilities of ‘actor-manager’ in 1878 when he assumed the management of the Lyceum, and remained there until 1902, enjoying star status with his leading lady Ellen Terry (1847-1928).   Irving produced a diverse range of old and new plays at the Lyceum, including Shakespeare, historical drama, and literary adaptations.  His tireless work to elevate the status of the theatrical profession was rewarded in 1895 when he became the first actor ever to receive a knighthood for services to the Theatre.

Irving specialised in spectacularly staged productions with large casts of performers. He commissioned designers and composers to create appropriate scenery, costume and incidental music, played by a full orchestra.  Although electric lighting was available from the 1880s, Irving preferred the softer effects of gas, with lime light to focus attention at key points in the play.  Irving toured complete productions outside London, taking the full company, scenery and costumes throughout the United Kingdom and across the United States and Canada.   The development of the railway system made his the first generation able to achieve this level of touring productions.
